awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: Noise, Attention and Performance
awd_abstract_narration:
Noise pollution is pervasive around the globe and predicted to grow in extent, frequency and severity (Goines and Hagler 2007). Decades of cognitive science research has established that noise negatively affects the learning and attainments of school children (ex. Shield and Dockrell 2003; Evans and Lepore 1993), while recent work in economics has shown that noise also lowers worker productivity (Dean 2017). However, the exact mechanism through which noise impairs performance and productivity remains uncertain and unquantified. This project aims at examining the importance of an often-suggested mechanism, which is attention. While central to economic behavior, only recent advances enable costs of attention to be quantified (Caplin et al. 2018). This project will apply this new measurement method and be the first to quantify the costs of noise in terms of attention. This project will also assess to what extent individuals are aware of these cost impacts. The ability to obtain unconfounded cost estimates of noise, and know whether these costs are correctly perceived, have important implications for policy makers. Whether the detrimental effects of noise pollution are correctly perceived determines whether awareness and educational campaigns, or active noise control strategies should be the policy maker's priority. Better estimates of the costs of noise are a crucial input for the valuation of noise abatement strategies such as building of acoustic barriers, changes in road profiles, traffic restrictions, and urban planning based on noise maps. In addition, this work will help better assess the location of schools and design of workplaces.

In order to quantify the costs of noise, a theoretical framework will be combined together with a lab experiment. The theoretical framework serves as a precise and objective measurement device that allows costs of attention to be recovered from choice data in the same way as costs of production can be recovered in competitive supply. Building on this framework, noise is modeled as: (i) a change in the marginal costs of attention, (ii) a direct disutility, and (iii) beliefs about the productivity impacts of noise. Then, an experiment is designed to estimate the costs of attention of two common sources of noise pollution in practice: speech and city noise. After participants work on an incentivized task - both under quiet and noisy conditions, their beliefs about their performance as well as their willingness to pay (WTP) for a final round in quiet conditions will be elicited. Comparing these beliefs and WTP to the participants? estimated costs will shed light on awareness of noise impacts and adoption of protective measures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project examines to what extent workers are aware of factors affecting their productivity and invest in their productivity, using the case of interruptions. Interruptions, defined as interferences shifting workers' attention away from their task at hand, are commonplace in today's work environment, both in offices and at home. Among others, these include emails, messages, phone calls, and someone stopping by. Specifically, this project addresses four research goals.

First, this project examines to what extent interruptions affect worker productivity and earnings. In an online experiment, each participant works on a representative real-work task with and without interruptions, where interruptions are incoming emails requiring a short but immediate response. Interruptions leave no worker unaffected but affect earnings and productivity in different ways. While workers earn on average less, not few benefit from interruptions and earn more. Working more accurately to compensate for a lower output quantity is only one of the various ways participants can trade off the quantity and quality of their work. Second, this project examines to what extent workers are aware of these productivity and earnings impacts. After participants completed the real-work task both with and without interruptions, their beliefs over their work performance are elicited in an incentivized manner. Unawareness is widespread among workers, especially of adopted quantity-quality trade-offs, and many are unaware to a considerable extent. Third, this project examines to what extent workers invest in their productivity. Participants can invest in their productivity by paying to eliminate interruptions in additional rounds of the same task. Productivity investments are not more commonly made by workers predicted to benefit more from them and workers who complete the final rounds of the task interruption-free do not recoup this costly investment via higher earnings. And fourth, this project assesses to what extent workers seek individual performance feedback. Before deciding whether to eliminate interruptions, some workers can pay to obtain feedback on their productivity with and without interruptions. Feedback receipt raises productivity investments but does not increase the likelihood of workers investing optimally.

By examining to what extent interruptions affect worker productivity and earnings, this project adds to the knowledge base of the economics literature. While economists have long recognized that physical and human capital can raise worker productivity, recent research suggests that also psychological and cognitive channels can affect worker productivity. Despite interruptions' pervasiveness nowadays, their economic impacts remain understudied. To shed light on heterogeneous effects, this project was designed to estimate individual-level impacts in addition to average effects. Interruptions are also studied by many disciplines outside economics--from psychology and neuroscience to information systems and management and organization science. This project contributes to these disciplines by directly linking earnings to productivity on a representative real-work task and ruling out mechanical effects by design. This project also advances the knowledge base on workers' awareness and productivity investments. The scant evidence existing to date suggests that workers might not understand how environments can affect their productivity and fail to take actions to protect their productivity. This project adds to this literature by eliciting individuals' beliefs about their own work performance when exposed to interruptions and when working uninterruptedly. The elicitation format permits studying magnitudes of perceived interruption-induced productivity and earnings effects in addition to directional effects. Quantifying workers' (un)awareness by comparing their perceived to their actual effects not only contributes to the economics literature knowledge- and method-wise, but also adds to disciplines outside of economics. Furthermore, this project innovates by experimentally enabling participants to invest in their productivity and allowing some participants to obtain individual-specific feedback before making this decision. This advances knowledge of workers' use of protective measures and what can influence these decisions across disciplines.

Many factors can influence how productive workers are and how much income they are able to generate. As interruptions are ubiquitous in today's work environments, better understanding their adverse effects benefits society as a whole. The here estimated effects suggest that limiting workers' exposure to interruptions could have economic as well as non-monetary benefits. Moreover, interruptions' heterogenous impacts highlight that self-awareness is an important skill for exploiting one's full earnings potential. Workers not understanding the consequences of being exposed to interruptions means that awareness and educational campaigns could be valuable. These campaigns could be followed up with interventions raising workers' self-awareness, e.g. tools helping workers learn what factors affect their productivity and by how much. Sub-optimal productivity investments combined with widespread unawareness among workers could also call for firms stepping in and creating environments conducive to productive work.
